subject: Re: [junit] Documenting test cases
msgSnippet: ... No apology necessary. I m glad you got the feedback you needed. -- J. B. Rainsberger, Diaspar Software Services http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416
messageBody:
David Plass wrote:

> JB,
> Disclaimer: I'm not really as stubborn as I've been sounding today. I
> actually agree with using 'throws Exception' . Recently I was burned on a
> checkstyle "code review" of my testing package that tagged me on *every*
> instance of 'throws Exception' (too general) *and* tagged me that I didn't
> document them (no @throws). I *knew* I was using the commonly-accepted
> idiom, but my confidence was shot down. I guess I wanted to hear what
> people thought about it, and explore the alternatives, and to reassure
> myself that I was really doing the right thing all along by just throwing
> Exception (and not necessarily documenting it.)
>
> Thanks & apologies if anyone felt I was stringing the group along.

No apology necessary. I'm glad you got the feedback you needed.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
